newsitem.title: CANADA: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool plans hog deals.
newsitem.headline: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool plans hog deals.

text.p: Saskatchewan Wheat Pool plans to diversify into hog production by courting pork producers into tapping their expertise ahead of a "dramatic" rise in output, a SWP director told Manitoba Pool Elevators delegates.

"A number of communities are meeting with management. We hope to be a catalyst to dramatically increase the amount of pork that's produced in Saskatchewan. We would provide some of the expertise to producers," SWP director Marvin Wiens said.
Canada's largest grain handler said in August it planned to expand into the pork industry.
Canada exported 341.05 million tonnes of pork in calendar 1995, valued at C$967.55 million, Agriculture Canada statistics show.

"We will do it either through community groups and there has been discussion of doing it through something like the closed cooperative systems they have in North and South Dakota," Wiens told the MPE delegates.
MPE delegates presented a motion at their annual meeting that MPE consider diversifying into the hog industry.
Manitoba was the first Canadian province to end its hog export monopoly July 1, 1996.
Saskatchewan is investigating whether it should end its marketing monopoly.
World pork consumption was forecast to increase by 750,000 tonnes a year while Saskatchewan's annual output is 100,000 tonnes, Wiens said.
"Saskatchewan is one of the lowest cost areas to raise pork. We envision this (production) growing dramatically in the next couple of years," Wiens said.
Manitoba produced 2.5 million hogs, Saskatchewan produced 1.0 million and Alberta produced 3.0 million hogs last year, the respective hog marketing groups said.
Alberta will be the second Canadian province to do so when it ends its hog export monopoly December 2, 1996, Alberta's Agriculture Minister Walter Paszkowski said on Wednesday.

"Strategic planning is part of the role that I play at Alberta Wheat Pool and whether that's an issue we should be involving ourselves in is a decision we'll be making a little further down the road," AWP first vice-president John Pearson told Reuters.
